The attacks occurred after Israels interior security service Shin Beth had warned of a terror attack in the region and massive Israeli troops had been stationed in the area. The militants first opened fire at an Egged No.392 bus as it was traveling on ... Add to Bag Thank you for requesting this book as a NOOK book from the publisher. Sending request ... Advertising Overview High Quality Content by WIKIPEDIA articles! On August 18, 2011, a series of cross-border attacks with parallel attacks and mutual cover was carried out in southern Israel on Highway 12 near the Egyptian border by a squad of presumably 12 militants in four groups. The attacks occurred after Israels interior security service Shin Beth had warned of a terror attack in the region and massive Israeli troops had been stationed in the area. The militants first opened fire at an Egged No.392 bus as it was traveling on Highway 12 in the Negev near Eilat. Several minutes later, a bomb was detonated next to an Israeli army patrol along Israel's border with Egypt. In a third attack, an anti-tank missile hit a private vehicle, killing four civilians. Eight Israelis - six civilians, one Yamam special Unit police officer and one Golani Brigade soldier-were killed in the multiple-stage attack. The Israeli security forces reported eight attackers killed, and Egyptian security forces reported killing another two.     2011 Southern Israel Cross-border Attacks Pictures, Images

    2011 southern israel cross-border attacks Pictures & Images   (1,713,362 results) Get Deals, Giveaways & More "...the prints have made many people so happy that they cried when they received them. Thank you!!" Website Help
    2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings - Wikipedia, the free ... 3 April 2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombing; Location: Dera Ghazi Khan District, Punjab, Pakistan: Coordinates Coordinates: Date: 3 April 2011 ... Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The attack was a double suicide bombing that left more than 50 people dead, as well as 120 wounded. [1] The bombings occurred while thousands of devotees were gathered for the annual Urs celebrations at the shrine. Urs are an integral part of South Asian Muslim culture and are held to mark the death anniversary of a Sufi. At around 5 pm PST , a teenaged bomber detonated his explosives while devotees were performing a mystical devotional dance at the main entrance to the building. Many of those wounded were in a critical condition. Approximately fifteen minutes later, a second suicide bomber also struck at the staircase of the shrine. A witness reported: "Bodies were scattered all over and the injured people were crying for help." [1] According to police officials, both the bombers tried to enter the shrine but being unsuccessful, blew themselves up on the entrance. A third suicide bomber was also recognized and arrested; [3] While people were running in panic, the bomber by chance ran into an elderly woman and a hand grenade dropped from his hand. [1] The woman signaled alarm and nearby security officials opened fire on him which left him wounded. The attempted suicide bomber was identified as Umar or "Fida Hussain", a teenager Afghan refugee hailing from the tribal areas in northwest Pakistan. [1] He writhed on the ground while people took away his equipment. [5] Following the explosion, a state of emergency was declared and victims were shifted to various hospitals in Dera Ghazi Khan and nearby Multan . The death toll mounted as several people succumbed to their injuries in the various hospitals. [6] It is said[ by whom? ] that the shrine had previously received threats from unknown militants. The Pakistani Taliban later claimed responsibility for the attacks. [2] The shrine reopened the following day. [7] Two days after the attack, the police claimed that it had identified the masterminds behind the bombing and that arrests were about to be carried out. According to investigators, the planning for the bombing had been carried out in the Bajaur Agency in the tribal areas along the Afghan border. [8] Two of the suicide bombers were from North Waziristan ; they had received their vests from handlers based in Dera Ismail Khan and later travelled to Dera Ghazi Khan, booking themselves a room at a hotel. [8] Umar, who failed to detonate his explosives, told interrogators that he had been told he would be granted paradise if he conducted the attack. He referred to himself as a " Fida'i " (meaning one who sacrifices their life for a cause), a term which militants often use for suicide bombers. When questioned how he would get into paradise by attacking people, he replied: "I don’t know about that but paradise must be better than this world." [8] A statement from the office of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani condemned the blast, stating "such cowardly acts of terror clearly demonstrate that the culprits involved neither have any faith nor any belief in human values. Such violent acts only seem to be conspiracy to divide the society and create fear." [1] This page was last modified on 20 December 2014, at 11:17. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings - Wikipedia, the free

    Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The attack was a double suicide bombing that left more than 50 people dead, as well as 120 wounded. [1] The bombings occurred while thousands of devotees were gathered for the annual Urs celebrations at the shrine. Urs are an integral part of South Asian Muslim culture and are held to mark the death anniversary of a Sufi. At around 5 pm PST , a teenaged bomber detonated his explosives while devotees were performing a mystical devotional dance at the main entrance to the building. Many of those wounded were in a critical condition. Approximately fifteen minutes later, a second suicide bomber also struck at the staircase of the shrine. A witness reported: "Bodies were scattered all over and the injured people were crying for help." [1] According to police officials, both the bombers tried to enter the shrine but being unsuccessful, blew themselves up on the entrance. A third suicide bomber was also recognized and arrested; [3] While people were running in panic, the bomber by chance ran into an elderly woman and a hand grenade dropped from his hand. [1] The woman signaled alarm and nearby security officials opened fire on him which left him wounded. The attempted suicide bomber was identified as Umar or "Fida Hussain", a teenager Afghan refugee hailing from the tribal areas in northwest Pakistan. [1] He writhed on the ground while people took away his equipment. [5] Following the explosion, a state of emergency was declared and victims were shifted to various hospitals in Dera Ghazi Khan and nearby Multan . The death toll mounted as several people succumbed to their injuries in the various hospitals. [6] It is said[ by whom? ] that the shrine had previously received threats from unknown militants. The Pakistani Taliban later claimed responsibility for the attacks. [2] The shrine reopened the following day. [7] Two days after the attack, the police claimed that it had identified the masterminds behind the bombing and that arrests were about to be carried out. According to investigators, the planning for the bombing had been carried out in the Bajaur Agency in the tribal areas along the Afghan border. [8] Two of the suicide bombers were from North Waziristan ; they had received their vests from handlers based in Dera Ismail Khan and later travelled to Dera Ghazi Khan, booking themselves a room at a hotel. [8] Umar, who failed to detonate his explosives, told interrogators that he had been told he would be granted paradise if he conducted the attack. He referred to himself as a " Fida'i " (meaning one who sacrifices their life for a cause), a term which militants often use for suicide bombers. When questioned how he would get into paradise by attacking people, he replied: "I don’t know about that but paradise must be better than this world." [8] A statement from the office of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani condemned the blast, stating "such cowardly acts of terror clearly demonstrate that the culprits involved neither have any faith nor any belief in human values. Such violent acts only seem to be conspiracy to divide the society and create fear." [1] This page was last modified on 20 December 2014, at 11:17. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.
    Talk:2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings - Wikipedia, the free ... Main page; Contents; Featured content; Current events; Random article; Donate to Wikipedia; Wikipedia store This is not a forum for general discussion of the article's subject.           This article is of interest to the following WikiProjects : This article is within the scope of WikiProject Pakistan , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of Pakistan on Wikipedia. If you would like to participate, please visit the project page, where you can join the discussion and see a list of open tasks.   This article is within the scope of WikiProject Terrorism , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of articles on individual terrorists, incidents and related subjects on Wikipedia. If you would like to participate, please visit the project page, where you can join the discussion and see a list of open tasks.   Possible correction of Location and Coordinates[ edit ] {{geodata-check}} Could someone please verify the correct location for this incident? The current Location may be confusing the "Dera Ghazi Khan" city with the district of the same name. And therefore the current Coordinates might be wrong as well. The page's Reference no. 1 (The Express Tribune) writes "at the shrine, sited some 40 kilometres away from Dera Ghazi Khan city", and the page's reference no. 2 (telegraph.co.uk) writes "13th century Sufi saint Ahmed Sultan, popularly known as Sakhi Sarwar, in Dera Ghazi Khan district". When I use Google Maps to search for the string "Sakhi Sarwar shrine in Dera Ghazi Khan, Punjab Province, Pakistan", I get 29°59′12″N 70°18′08″E﻿ / ﻿29.98656°N 70.30213°E﻿ / 29.98656; 70.30213 , which is also marked on Google Maps with an icon and title as "Sakhi Sarwar's shrine". And finally, the page's reference no. 7 is a newspaper article apparently written by a journalist stationed at Dera Ghazi Khan city, but says of the incident that it took place "at Darbar Sakhi Sarwar, some 35 kilometres from here" -- and according to Google Maps, 35 kilometers is the distance from Dera Ghazi Khan city westwards to the Sakhi Sarwar shrine. If my assumption is correct, then the problem is that the Location and Coordinates on the current version of the page seem to refer to the Dera Ghazi Khan city itself. So, could someone please verify that this page should be corrected to the Location of "Sakhi Sarwar shrine in Dera Ghazi Khan _district_, Punjab Province, Pakistan" and the Coordinates of 29°59′12″N 70°18′08″E﻿ / ﻿29.98656°N 70.30213°E﻿ / 29.98656; 70.30213  ? (By the way, if my assumption is correct, then there's another edit that should also be made in another page, i.e. the page for "Sakhi_Sarwar", section Incidents, which also points to the city itself -- with the phrase "In nearby Dera Ghazi Khan"...) Done After reviewing your evidence and other evidence, I've concluded that your analysis is spot on. In addition to the points you've adduced, note that the entrance building of the shrine (clearly visible in the Bing aerial view), the coordinates of which I've used, appears to match the building shown in the photo in reference 7. I've made the necessary changes in both this article and Sakhi Sarwar . Deor ( talk ) 11:35, 6 November 2013 (UTC) This page was last modified on 21 June 2014, at 08:19. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    Talk:2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings - Wikipedia, the free

    This is not a forum for general discussion of the article's subject.           This article is of interest to the following WikiProjects : This article is within the scope of WikiProject Pakistan , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of Pakistan on Wikipedia. If you would like to participate, please visit the project page, where you can join the discussion and see a list of open tasks.   This article is within the scope of WikiProject Terrorism , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of articles on individual terrorists, incidents and related subjects on Wikipedia. If you would like to participate, please visit the project page, where you can join the discussion and see a list of open tasks.   Possible correction of Location and Coordinates[ edit ] {{geodata-check}} Could someone please verify the correct location for this incident? The current Location may be confusing the "Dera Ghazi Khan" city with the district of the same name. And therefore the current Coordinates might be wrong as well. The page's Reference no. 1 (The Express Tribune) writes "at the shrine, sited some 40 kilometres away from Dera Ghazi Khan city", and the page's reference no. 2 (telegraph.co.uk) writes "13th century Sufi saint Ahmed Sultan, popularly known as Sakhi Sarwar, in Dera Ghazi Khan district". When I use Google Maps to search for the string "Sakhi Sarwar shrine in Dera Ghazi Khan, Punjab Province, Pakistan", I get 29°59′12″N 70°18′08″E﻿ / ﻿29.98656°N 70.30213°E﻿ / 29.98656; 70.30213 , which is also marked on Google Maps with an icon and title as "Sakhi Sarwar's shrine". And finally, the page's reference no. 7 is a newspaper article apparently written by a journalist stationed at Dera Ghazi Khan city, but says of the incident that it took place "at Darbar Sakhi Sarwar, some 35 kilometres from here" -- and according to Google Maps, 35 kilometers is the distance from Dera Ghazi Khan city westwards to the Sakhi Sarwar shrine. If my assumption is correct, then the problem is that the Location and Coordinates on the current version of the page seem to refer to the Dera Ghazi Khan city itself. So, could someone please verify that this page should be corrected to the Location of "Sakhi Sarwar shrine in Dera Ghazi Khan _district_, Punjab Province, Pakistan" and the Coordinates of 29°59′12″N 70°18′08″E﻿ / ﻿29.98656°N 70.30213°E﻿ / 29.98656; 70.30213  ? (By the way, if my assumption is correct, then there's another edit that should also be made in another page, i.e. the page for "Sakhi_Sarwar", section Incidents, which also points to the city itself -- with the phrase "In nearby Dera Ghazi Khan"...) Done After reviewing your evidence and other evidence, I've concluded that your analysis is spot on. In addition to the points you've adduced, note that the entrance building of the shrine (clearly visible in the Bing aerial view), the coordinates of which I've used, appears to match the building shown in the photo in reference 7. I've made the necessary changes in both this article and Sakhi Sarwar . Deor ( talk ) 11:35, 6 November 2013 (UTC) This page was last modified on 21 June 2014, at 08:19.     2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings | QuickiWiki What is QuickiWiki? QuickiWiki takes the amazing Wikipedia content and presents it to users using the latest technologies. Why? Wikipedia is based on community ... ✔  Quick: topics are summarized on a timeline ✔  Comprehensive: additional facts and information ✔  Modern: thumbnails for links and books ✔  Beautiful: x2 larger pictures + full-screen viewer ✔  Convenient: collapsible table of contents and keyboard navigation Take Wikipedia to the next level: ✔  Quick: topics are summarized on a timeline ✔  Comprehensive: additional facts and information ✔  Modern: thumbnails for links and books ✔  Beautiful: x2 larger pictures + full-screen viewer ✔  Convenient: collapsible table of contents and keyboard navigation Would you like to upgrade your Wikipedia? Yes No What is QuickiWiki? QuickiWiki takes the amazing Wikipedia content and presents it to users using the latest technologies. Why? Wikipedia is based on community contributions and financial donations. The first part works amazing: people all over the world collaborating to create the world's largest encyclopedia. The second part – well, it seems that people are not as cooperative when it comes to their wallets: Wikipedia's budget is very limited, resulting in a website that looks more like a private blog than the world's 6th largest site (I mean, images that open in a new page? Really?) QuickiWiki allows people to access Wikipedia's content through a quicker and more modern interface, enhancing it with images, videos and more (How about being able to play the movie trailer from within the film's page?) Hey! Aren't you stealing Wikipedia's work? Quite the opposite. Wikimedia (the awesome people behind Wikipedia) have made all its content free and available to all humankind. Actually, by using QuickiWiki you are reducing load from Wikipedia's servers and saving them money! Cool idea. I'm in! 2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings Location 2 bombers, another one arrested [3] A pair of bombings occurred on 3 April 2011 in a Sufi shrine dedicated to a 13th-century Sufi saint, Ahmed Sultan, located near the city of Dera Ghazi Khan in the southern region of Pakistan 's largest province, Punjab . [1] Contents Background Sufism is a Muslim culture that has thrived in the Indian subcontinent and involves the belief that one can feel a linked connection with God through spirituality. In Pakistan, the Punjab region has been a historical hub of Sufi culture. Sufism and Sufi traditions are regarded as heretical by hard-line Islamists. In Sufi shrines devotees pray to saints while singing and dancing and this is considered un-Islamic by the Taliban . Several Sufi shrines in Pakistan have been targeted in the past by the Taliban. [4] Attack The attack was a double suicide bombing that left more than 50 people dead, as well as 120 wounded. [1] The bombings occurred while thousands of devotees were gathered for the annual Urs celebrations at the shrine. Urs are an integral part of South Asian Muslim culture and are held to mark the death anniversary of a Sufi. At around 5 pm PST , a teenaged bomber detonated his explosives while devotees were performing a mystical devotional dance at the main entrance to the building. Many of those wounded were in a critical condition. Approximately fifteen minutes later, a second suicide bomber also struck at the staircase of the shrine. A witness reported: "Bodies were scattered all over and the injured people were crying for help." [1] According to police officials, both the bombers tried to enter the shrine but being unsuccessful, blew themselves up on the entrance. A third suicide bomber was also recognized and arrested; [3] While people were running in panic, the bomber by chance ran into an elderly woman and a hand grenade dropped from his hand. [1] The woman signaled alarm and nearby security officials opened fire on him which left him wounded. The attempted suicide bomber was identified as Umar or "Fida Hussain", a teenager Afghan refugee hailing from the tribal areas in northwest Pakistan. [1] He writhed on the ground while people took away his equipment. [5] Aftermath Following the explosion, a state of emergency was declared and victims were shifted to various hospitals in Dera Ghazi Khan and nearby Multan . The death toll mounted as several people succumbed to their injuries in the various hospitals. [6] It is said[ by whom? ] that the shrine had previously received threats from unknown militants. The Pakistani Taliban later claimed responsibility for the attacks. [2] The shrine reopened the following day. [7] Investigations Two days after the attack, the police claimed that it had identified the masterminds behind the bombing and that arrests were about to be carried out. According to investigators, the planning for the bombing had been carried out in the Bajaur Agency in the tribal areas along the Afghan border. [8] Two of the suicide bombers were from North Waziristan ; they had received their vests from handlers based in Dera Ismail Khan and later travelled to Dera Ghazi Khan, booking themselves a room at a hotel. [8] Umar, who failed to detonate his explosives, told interrogators that he had been told he would be granted paradise if he conducted the attack. He referred to himself as a " Fida'i " (meaning one who sacrifices their life for a cause), a term which militants often use for suicide bombers. When questioned how he would get into paradise by attacking people, he replied: "I don’t know about that but paradise must be better than this world." [8] Response A statement from the office of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani condemned the blast, stating "such cowardly acts of terror clearly demonstrate that the culprits involved neither have any faith nor any belief in human values. Such violent acts only seem to be conspiracy to divide the society and create fear." [1] References ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date *6 December 2012, 15:46:01 Source: *www.flickr.com ©

    2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings | QuickiWiki What is QuickiWiki? QuickiWiki takes the amazing Wikipedia content and presents it to users using the latest technologies. Why? Wikipedia is based on community

    ✔  Quick: topics are summarized on a timeline ✔  Comprehensive: additional facts and information ✔  Modern: thumbnails for links and books ✔  Beautiful: x2 larger pictures + full-screen viewer ✔  Convenient: collapsible table of contents and keyboard navigation Take Wikipedia to the next level: ✔  Quick: topics are summarized on a timeline ✔  Comprehensive: additional facts and information ✔  Modern: thumbnails for links and books ✔  Beautiful: x2 larger pictures + full-screen viewer ✔  Convenient: collapsible table of contents and keyboard navigation Would you like to upgrade your Wikipedia? Yes No What is QuickiWiki? QuickiWiki takes the amazing Wikipedia content and presents it to users using the latest technologies. Why? Wikipedia is based on community contributions and financial donations. The first part works amazing: people all over the world collaborating to create the world's largest encyclopedia. The second part – well, it seems that people are not as cooperative when it comes to their wallets: Wikipedia's budget is very limited, resulting in a website that looks more like a private blog than the world's 6th largest site (I mean, images that open in a new page? Really?) QuickiWiki allows people to access Wikipedia's content through a quicker and more modern interface, enhancing it with images, videos and more (How about being able to play the movie trailer from within the film's page?) Hey! Aren't you stealing Wikipedia's work? Quite the opposite. Wikimedia (the awesome people behind Wikipedia) have made all its content free and available to all humankind. Actually, by using QuickiWiki you are reducing load from Wikipedia's servers and saving them money! Cool idea. I'm in! 2011 Dera Ghazi Khan bombings Location 2 bombers, another one arrested [3] A pair of bombings occurred on 3 April 2011 in a Sufi shrine dedicated to a 13th-century Sufi saint, Ahmed Sultan, located near the city of Dera Ghazi Khan in the southern region of Pakistan 's largest province, Punjab . [1] Contents Background Sufism is a Muslim culture that has thrived in the Indian subcontinent and involves the belief that one can feel a linked connection with God through spirituality. In Pakistan, the Punjab region has been a historical hub of Sufi culture. Sufism and Sufi traditions are regarded as heretical by hard-line Islamists. In Sufi shrines devotees pray to saints while singing and dancing and this is considered un-Islamic by the Taliban . Several Sufi shrines in Pakistan have been targeted in the past by the Taliban. [4] Attack The attack was a double suicide bombing that left more than 50 people dead, as well as 120 wounded. [1] The bombings occurred while thousands of devotees were gathered for the annual Urs celebrations at the shrine. Urs are an integral part of South Asian Muslim culture and are held to mark the death anniversary of a Sufi. At around 5 pm PST , a teenaged bomber detonated his explosives while devotees were performing a mystical devotional dance at the main entrance to the building. Many of those wounded were in a critical condition. Approximately fifteen minutes later, a second suicide bomber also struck at the staircase of the shrine. A witness reported: "Bodies were scattered all over and the injured people were crying for help." [1] According to police officials, both the bombers tried to enter the shrine but being unsuccessful, blew themselves up on the entrance. A third suicide bomber was also recognized and arrested; [3] While people were running in panic, the bomber by chance ran into an elderly woman and a hand grenade dropped from his hand. [1] The woman signaled alarm and nearby security officials opened fire on him which left him wounded. The attempted suicide bomber was identified as Umar or "Fida Hussain", a teenager Afghan refugee hailing from the tribal areas in northwest Pakistan. [1] He writhed on the ground while people took away his equipment. [5] Aftermath Following the explosion, a state of emergency was declared and victims were shifted to various hospitals in Dera Ghazi Khan and nearby Multan . The death toll mounted as several people succumbed to their injuries in the various hospitals. [6] It is said[ by whom? ] that the shrine had previously received threats from unknown militants. The Pakistani Taliban later claimed responsibility for the attacks. [2] The shrine reopened the following day. [7] Investigations Two days after the attack, the police claimed that it had identified the masterminds behind the bombing and that arrests were about to be carried out. According to investigators, the planning for the bombing had been carried out in the Bajaur Agency in the tribal areas along the Afghan border. [8] Two of the suicide bombers were from North Waziristan ; they had received their vests from handlers based in Dera Ismail Khan and later travelled to Dera Ghazi Khan, booking themselves a room at a hotel. [8] Umar, who failed to detonate his explosives, told interrogators that he had been told he would be granted paradise if he conducted the attack. He referred to himself as a " Fida'i " (meaning one who sacrifices their life for a cause), a term which militants often use for suicide bombers. When questioned how he would get into paradise by attacking people, he replied: "I don’t know about that but paradise must be better than this world." [8] Response A statement from the office of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani condemned the blast, stating "such cowardly acts of terror clearly demonstrate that the culprits involved neither have any faith nor any belief in human values. Such violent acts only seem to be conspiracy to divide the society and create fear." [1] References ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date *6 December 2012, 15:46:01 Source: *www.flickr.com ©
    2011 Dera Ghazi Khan Bombings Pictures ... - Photobucket Browse / 2011 dera ghazi khan bombings; 2011 dera ghazi khan bombings Pictures & Images ... 2011 dera ghazi khan bombings Pictures & Images   (1,634,308 results) Website Help

    2011 Dera Ghazi Khan Bombings Pictures

    2011 dera ghazi khan bombings Pictures & Images   (1,634,308 results) Website Help
    April 2010 Kohat bombings - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia The April 2010 Kohat bombings were a pair of bombings that struck a center for displaced people on the outskirts of the town of Kohat, in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan ... Jump to: navigation , search April 2010 Kohat bombings Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The bombings happened at the Kacha Pukha camp, [4] set up for internally displaced persons that had fled the Orakzai tribal area in north-west Pakistan near the Afghanistan border. [3] The victims were among 300 people [5] queued to register for aid at the camp. [6] The suicide bombers were reported to be wearing burqas , [7] and having set off their bombs within minutes of each other. [6] Most of the victims were from Baramad Khel and Mani Khel tribes who had fled fighting in Orakzai Agency . [8] The next day another suicide bomber attacked a police station in response to military operations in Kohat killing 7 and wounding 21. The police chief of Kohat, Dilawar Khan Bangash, said: "It was a suicide attack. The target was a police station. The bomber exploded his vehicle on the back side of the police station. These incidents are a reaction to the military operation in the tribal areas." [9] In the aftermath of the bombings, the United Nations temporarily suspended operations assisting refugees in the Kohat region. [11] There are more than 200,000 internally displaced persons in the area of the incident. [12] Pakistan's Defence Minister, Ahmad Mukhtar , called the attacks "highly barbaric and cowardly." [1] ^ Sajjad, Mohammad (17 April 2010). "Pakistan: Bombers kill refugees waiting for food" . The Associated Press. Archived from the original on 20 April 2010. Retrieved 17 April 2010.  ^ a b Shah, Pir Zubair (17 April 2010). "Suicide Bombers Strike Refugees in Pakistan" . The New York Times. Archived from the original on 21 April 2010. Retrieved 17 April 2010.  This page was last modified on 20 December 2014, at 11:19. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    April 2010 Kohat bombings - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia The April 2010 Kohat bombings were a pair of bombings that struck a center for displaced people on the outskirts of the town of Kohat, in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan

    Jump to: navigation , search April 2010 Kohat bombings Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The bombings happened at the Kacha Pukha camp, [4] set up for internally displaced persons that had fled the Orakzai tribal area in north-west Pakistan near the Afghanistan border. [3] The victims were among 300 people [5] queued to register for aid at the camp. [6] The suicide bombers were reported to be wearing burqas , [7] and having set off their bombs within minutes of each other. [6] Most of the victims were from Baramad Khel and Mani Khel tribes who had fled fighting in Orakzai Agency . [8] The next day another suicide bomber attacked a police station in response to military operations in Kohat killing 7 and wounding 21. The police chief of Kohat, Dilawar Khan Bangash, said: "It was a suicide attack. The target was a police station. The bomber exploded his vehicle on the back side of the police station. These incidents are a reaction to the military operation in the tribal areas." [9] In the aftermath of the bombings, the United Nations temporarily suspended operations assisting refugees in the Kohat region. [11] There are more than 200,000 internally displaced persons in the area of the incident. [12] Pakistan's Defence Minister, Ahmad Mukhtar , called the attacks "highly barbaric and cowardly." [1] ^ Sajjad, Mohammad (17 April 2010). "Pakistan: Bombers kill refugees waiting for food" . The Associated Press. Archived from the original on 20 April 2010. Retrieved 17 April 2010.  ^ a b Shah, Pir Zubair (17 April 2010). "Suicide Bombers Strike Refugees in Pakistan" . The New York Times. Archived from the original on 21 April 2010. Retrieved 17 April 2010.  This page was last modified on 20 December 2014, at 11:19. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.
    Talk:April 2010 Kohat bombings - Wikipedia, the free ... Untitled . Under the responsibility section, the group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi is purported to have claimed responsibility. But citation #6, a New York Times article, does ... This is not a forum for general discussion of the article's subject.           This article is of interest to the following WikiProjects : This article is within the scope of WikiProject Pakistan , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of Pakistan on Wikipedia. If you would like to participate, please visit the project page, where you can join the discussion and see a list of open tasks.     Under the responsibility section, the group Lashkar-e-Jhangvi is purported to have claimed responsibility. But citation #6, a New York Times article, does not mention this group anywhere. Simply English ( talk ) 16:46, 20 April 2010 (UTC) Hmm... the NYT article has changed some since I looked at it last. I changed the citation to another source, which says the same thing. Courcelles ( talk ) 16:51, 20 April 2010 (UTC) This page was last modified on 21 June 2014, at 08:29.     This is not a forum for general discussion of the article's subject.           This article is of interest to the following WikiProjects : This article is within the scope of WikiProject Pakistan , a collaborative effort to improve the coverage of Pakistan on Wikipedia.     The April 2010 Kohat bombings | Fundstellen im Internet ... Der Begriff The April 2010 Kohat bombings ist im englisch-sprachigen Wikipedia aufgeführt. Dort heißt es dazu: The April 2010 Kohat bombings were a pair of bombings ... Der Begriff The April 2010 Kohat bombings ist im englisch-sprachigen Wikipedia aufgeführt. Dort heißt es dazu: The April 2010 Kohat bombings were a pair of bombings that struck a center for displaced people on the outskirts of the town of Kohat , in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa , Pakistan , on April 17, 2010. At least 41 people were killed, while another 64 more were injured. The next day another suicide bombing at a police station killed 7 more and injured nearly two dozen. Dies ist ein Auszug aus dem Artikel The April 2010 Kohat bombings der freien Enzyklopädie Wikipedia. In der Wikipedia ist eine Liste der Autoren verfügbar. Auf de.wikipedia.org wurde der Artikel The April 2010 Kohat bombings in den letzten 30 Tagen 3-mal aufgerufen. (Stand: 17.05.2014) Bilder zu The April 2010 Kohat bombings Hier sind noch keine Daten vorhanden... Mit dieser gelungenen Anleitung werden die Leser auch ohne Vorkenntnisse schon bald wunderschöne Tabellen und Diagramme erstellen können. In diesem umfassenden Nachschlagewerk finden Sie alles, was Sie für die Arbeit mit Microsoft Access 2010 benötigen: vom Schnelleinstieg über die Grundlagen des Datenbankdesigns bis hin zur Erstellung kompletter Anwendungen. Der erfahrene Softwaredozent und Datenbankexperte Lorenz Hölscher zeigt anschaulich anhand von Beispieldatenbanken, worauf es ... Zum Werk Das Werk aus der Reihe Grundrisse des Rechts geht vornehmlich zwei Problemkreisen nach: Zum einen befasst es sich mit der Bestimmung des Phänomens "Recht", zum anderen mit den Kriterien des "Richtigen". Beide Problembereiche können nicht unbesehen der Normsetzung durch den Gesetzgeber noch der richterlichen Entscheidung... Mehr cyclopaedia-Einträge

    The April 2010 Kohat bombings | Fundstellen im Internet

    Der Begriff The April 2010 Kohat bombings ist im englisch-sprachigen Wikipedia aufgeführt. Dort heißt es dazu: The April 2010 Kohat bombings were a pair of bombings that struck a center for displaced people on the outskirts of the town of Kohat , in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa , Pakistan , on April 17, 2010. At least 41 people were killed, while another 64 more were injured. The next day another suicide bombing at a police station killed 7 more and injured nearly two dozen. Dies ist ein Auszug aus dem Artikel The April 2010 Kohat bombings der freien Enzyklopädie Wikipedia. In der Wikipedia ist eine Liste der Autoren verfügbar. Auf de.wikipedia.org wurde der Artikel The April 2010 Kohat bombings in den letzten 30 Tagen 3-mal aufgerufen. (Stand: 17.05.2014) Bilder zu The April 2010 Kohat bombings Hier sind noch keine Daten vorhanden... KGaA, 2010 Wer an Tabellen denkt, denkt automatisch an Excel, zumindest wenn er sie auf dem Computer erstellt. In diesem Buch stellt Greg Harvey das neue Excel vor, das 2010 auf den Markt kommt. Mit dieser gelungenen Anleitung werden die Leser auch ohne Vorkenntnisse schon bald wunderschöne Tabellen und Diagramme erstellen können. In diesem umfassenden Nachschlagewerk finden Sie alles, was Sie für die Arbeit mit Microsoft Access 2010 benötigen: vom Schnelleinstieg über die Grundlagen des Datenbankdesigns bis hin zur Erstellung kompletter Anwendungen. Der erfahrene Softwaredozent und Datenbankexperte Lorenz Hölscher zeigt anschaulich anhand von Beispieldatenbanken, worauf es ... Zum Werk Das Werk aus der Reihe Grundrisse des Rechts geht vornehmlich zwei Problemkreisen nach: Zum einen befasst es sich mit der Bestimmung des Phänomens "Recht", zum anderen mit den Kriterien des "Richtigen".     19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing - Wikipedia, the free ... The 19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing was a suicide bombing that occurred in a marketplace in Peshawar , Pakistan on 19 April 2010. At least 25 people died. The blast ... (May 2010) Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Content is available under CC BY-SA 3.0 unless otherwise noted.

    19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing - Wikipedia, the free

    (May 2010) Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Content is available under CC BY-SA 3.0 unless otherwise noted.
    May 2010 Kabul bombing - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia The May 2010 Kabul bombing occurred on May 18, 2010, in Kabul, Afghanistan. Eighteen people including five US soldiers and a Canadian soldier were killed and fifty ... Jump to: navigation , search May 2010 Kabul bombing Contents President Hamid Karzai had recently returned from a trip to US to gather support for his policy to promote peace and reconciliation in Afghanistan. A jirga was planned to discuss methods to promote peace with the tribal elders. Also a military offensive was being planned in the Kandahar Province . Shortly before this attack Taliban had announced 'Operation al-Fatah' that would target NATO forces, foreign diplomats, contractors and Afghan government. [3] Afghan police had set up several extra security checkpoints this year. In spite of these measures the bomber was able to drive his vehicle into the city. [1] The bomber, driving a Toyota minivan packed with more than 1600 pounds of explosives, drove into a convoy of American military vehicles moving down the Dar-ul-Aman road at about 8 a.m. local time and exploded. [6] The blast created a deep crater in the road near the ruined Darul Aman Palace . [7] The bombing happened during the rush hour close to the National Assembly of Afghanistan . The blast destroyed 5 US military vehicles and 13 civilian vehicles. [8] Most of the dead were Afghan civilians including women and children in a public bus which was driving by when the explosion happened. [9] Five US soldiers were among the dead. The dead Canadian soldier was identified as Colonel Geoff Parker originally from Oakville, Ontario . He is the highest-ranked Canadian soldier killed in Afghanistan. [10] [2] An American colonel, 2 American lieutenant colonels and their 2 American drivers were also killed. [11] The American officers were identified as colonel John M. McHugh, 46, from New Jersey and lieutenant colonels, Paul R. Bartz, 43, of Waterloo, Wisconsin , and Thomas P. Belkofer, 44, of Perrysburg, Ohio . [4] The Taliban took responsibility for the attack. [7] They stated that they had sent a man named Nizamuddin to carry out the attack. Several analysts believe that the attack reflected Taliban opposition to the upcoming peace jirga proposed by President Hamid Karzai . [12] According to Afghanistan's spy agency the attack was allegedly carried out by Pakistan' spy agency Inter-Services Intelligence . Saeed Ansari a spokesman for National Directorate of Security, Afghanistan’s spy agency stated that 'All the explosions and terrorist attacks by these people were plotted from the other side of the border and most of the explosives and materials used for the attacks were brought from the other side to Afghanistan.' [11] According to US military intelligence officials Haqqani network based in Pakistan was also involved in the attack. [13] The attack drew strong condemnation from Anders Fogh Rasmussen , the Secretary General of NATO . [2] Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada in a statement condemned the attack and mourned Parker calling him a "great Canadian who will be greatly missed by the Canadian Forces family and his community." [14] This page was last modified on 14 December 2014, at 20:48. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    May 2010 Kabul bombing - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia The May 2010 Kabul bombing occurred on May 18, 2010, in Kabul, Afghanistan. Eighteen people including five US soldiers and a Canadian soldier were killed and fifty

    Jump to: navigation , search May 2010 Kabul bombing Contents President Hamid Karzai had recently returned from a trip to US to gather support for his policy to promote peace and reconciliation in Afghanistan. A jirga was planned to discuss methods to promote peace with the tribal elders. Also a military offensive was being planned in the Kandahar Province . Shortly before this attack Taliban had announced 'Operation al-Fatah' that would target NATO forces, foreign diplomats, contractors and Afghan government. [3] Afghan police had set up several extra security checkpoints this year. In spite of these measures the bomber was able to drive his vehicle into the city. [1] The bomber, driving a Toyota minivan packed with more than 1600 pounds of explosives, drove into a convoy of American military vehicles moving down the Dar-ul-Aman road at about 8 a.m. local time and exploded. [6] The blast created a deep crater in the road near the ruined Darul Aman Palace . [7] The bombing happened during the rush hour close to the National Assembly of Afghanistan . The blast destroyed 5 US military vehicles and 13 civilian vehicles. [8] Most of the dead were Afghan civilians including women and children in a public bus which was driving by when the explosion happened. [9] Five US soldiers were among the dead. The dead Canadian soldier was identified as Colonel Geoff Parker originally from Oakville, Ontario . He is the highest-ranked Canadian soldier killed in Afghanistan. [10] [2] An American colonel, 2 American lieutenant colonels and their 2 American drivers were also killed. [11] The American officers were identified as colonel John M. McHugh, 46, from New Jersey and lieutenant colonels, Paul R. Bartz, 43, of Waterloo, Wisconsin , and Thomas P. Belkofer, 44, of Perrysburg, Ohio . [4] The Taliban took responsibility for the attack. [7] They stated that they had sent a man named Nizamuddin to carry out the attack. Several analysts believe that the attack reflected Taliban opposition to the upcoming peace jirga proposed by President Hamid Karzai . [12] According to Afghanistan's spy agency the attack was allegedly carried out by Pakistan' spy agency Inter-Services Intelligence . Saeed Ansari a spokesman for National Directorate of Security, Afghanistan’s spy agency stated that 'All the explosions and terrorist attacks by these people were plotted from the other side of the border and most of the explosives and materials used for the attacks were brought from the other side to Afghanistan.' [11] According to US military intelligence officials Haqqani network based in Pakistan was also involved in the attack. [13] The attack drew strong condemnation from Anders Fogh Rasmussen , the Secretary General of NATO . [2] Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada in a statement condemned the attack and mourned Parker calling him a "great Canadian who will be greatly missed by the Canadian Forces family and his community." [14] This page was last modified on 14 December 2014, at 20:48. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.
    May 2010 Kabul bombing | INTELLIGENCE | WORLD KABUL, Afghanistan – Suicide bombers targeted Afghanistan's intelligence agency and other security forces in four coordinated attacks in the heart of Kabul and ... 25-2-2013   zxcvbnm0 KABUL, Afghanistan –  Suicide bombers targeted Afghanistan's intelligence agency and other security forces in four coordinated attacks in the heart of Kabul and outlying areas on Sunday in a bloody reminder of the insurgency's reach nearly 12 years into the 125 Things We’ve Learned About the NSA On 6 June 2013, Britain's The Guardian newspaper began publishing a series of revelations by an as yet unknown American whistleblower, revealed several days later to Read More » E.     April 2010 U.S consulate and ANP attack - Wikipedia, the ... On April 5, 2010, two bombings in Pakistan killed up to 50 people and injured 100 more. In the first attack the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar was attacked by militants ... From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia   (Redirected from 2010 Peshawar bombings ) Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The American consulate attack killed 8 people including 2 security service personnel. [6] However, no Americans were hurt in the attack. The perpetrators were armed with guns and grenades and two car bombs. The security barrier was damaged, while shells from rocket-propelled grenades and hand grenades were seen in the vicinity. Police said one of the car bombs exploded at a checkpoint 50 metres from the consulate, while the other 100 kg bomb went off close to the consulate gate. At least three blasts were reported before a firefight between security forces and the attackers followed. According to Pakistan police official Ghulam Hussain, "The target was certainly the American consulate but they didn't succeed in getting there...one of the suicide bombers blew himself up close to the gate. Police guarding the US consulate started retaliatory fire. More blasts took place. We have recovered unexploded material from four different points". [5] The US Consulate General said two Pakistani security guards employed by the Consulate General were among those killed in the attack. [2] Hours earlier 44 people died in a suicide attack at a rally in the north-western town of Timergara , Lower Dir District , during a meeting of the Awami National Party (ANP), the ruling coalition in North West Frontier Province . Zahid Khan, an Awami National Party spokesperson, said his party were celebrating plans to change the name of the North West Frontier Province when a suspected suicide bomber detonated his explosives. [8] An official of the ruling ANP party, Hashim Khan Babar, told the media the attacks appeared to be in response to a major security operation which was launched in the Orakzai tribal region near Peshawar last week. [7] Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility for the attacks in a telephone release by Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan spokesman Azam Tariq, with the statement “We accept the attacks on the American consulate. This is revenge for drone attacks. We have already told you that we have 2,800 to 3,000 fedayeen (suicide bombers). We will carry out more such attacks. We will target any place where there are Americans” [2] The attack was revenge for Drone attacks in Pakistan . [9] A BBC analyst said the Pakistani Taliban were apparently aiming for a feat to match the one last December in Khost, Afghanistan , in which several American CIA officials were killed. [7] An analyst in the capital said that after the government war on the Taliban the militants spread into more settled areas. He added that "The American consulate is one of the most well guarded places in Peshawar. It [the attack] was well planned and they very confidently hit their target." Al Jazeera's correspondent also noted that "Although they have been driven out of their strongholds in key areas, there is a feeling that a substantial number of those people have now infiltrated into the settled areas. There is trouble in the southern parts of the Punjab - so you do see some sort of regrouping attempt and a fear that there maybe an escalation of this sort of violence." [8] The United States embassy in Pakistan released a statement condemning the attack and saying that it reflected the "terrorists' desperation". [10] Robert Gibbs, the White House spokesmen, added: "We strongly condemn the violence and the actions. And I would point out that ... extremists in Pakistan have succeeded in killing Pakistanis, which I think hardens the view that has led to gains that have been made over the course of the year against extremism by native Pakistanis." [8] This page was last modified on 16 January 2015, at 21:27. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    April 2010 U.S consulate and ANP attack - Wikipedia, the

    From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia   (Redirected from 2010 Peshawar bombings ) Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents The American consulate attack killed 8 people including 2 security service personnel. [6] However, no Americans were hurt in the attack. The perpetrators were armed with guns and grenades and two car bombs. The security barrier was damaged, while shells from rocket-propelled grenades and hand grenades were seen in the vicinity. Police said one of the car bombs exploded at a checkpoint 50 metres from the consulate, while the other 100 kg bomb went off close to the consulate gate. At least three blasts were reported before a firefight between security forces and the attackers followed. According to Pakistan police official Ghulam Hussain, "The target was certainly the American consulate but they didn't succeed in getting there...one of the suicide bombers blew himself up close to the gate. Police guarding the US consulate started retaliatory fire. More blasts took place. We have recovered unexploded material from four different points". [5] The US Consulate General said two Pakistani security guards employed by the Consulate General were among those killed in the attack. [2] Hours earlier 44 people died in a suicide attack at a rally in the north-western town of Timergara , Lower Dir District , during a meeting of the Awami National Party (ANP), the ruling coalition in North West Frontier Province . Zahid Khan, an Awami National Party spokesperson, said his party were celebrating plans to change the name of the North West Frontier Province when a suspected suicide bomber detonated his explosives. [8] An official of the ruling ANP party, Hashim Khan Babar, told the media the attacks appeared to be in response to a major security operation which was launched in the Orakzai tribal region near Peshawar last week. [7] Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility for the attacks in a telephone release by Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan spokesman Azam Tariq, with the statement “We accept the attacks on the American consulate. This is revenge for drone attacks. We have already told you that we have 2,800 to 3,000 fedayeen (suicide bombers). We will carry out more such attacks. We will target any place where there are Americans” [2] The attack was revenge for Drone attacks in Pakistan . [9] A BBC analyst said the Pakistani Taliban were apparently aiming for a feat to match the one last December in Khost, Afghanistan , in which several American CIA officials were killed. [7] An analyst in the capital said that after the government war on the Taliban the militants spread into more settled areas. He added that "The American consulate is one of the most well guarded places in Peshawar. It [the attack] was well planned and they very confidently hit their target." Al Jazeera's correspondent also noted that "Although they have been driven out of their strongholds in key areas, there is a feeling that a substantial number of those people have now infiltrated into the settled areas. There is trouble in the southern parts of the Punjab - so you do see some sort of regrouping attempt and a fear that there maybe an escalation of this sort of violence." [8] The United States embassy in Pakistan released a statement condemning the attack and saying that it reflected the "terrorists' desperation". [10] Robert Gibbs, the White House spokesmen, added: "We strongly condemn the violence and the actions. And I would point out that ... extremists in Pakistan have succeeded in killing Pakistanis, which I think hardens the view that has led to gains that have been made over the course of the year against extremism by native Pakistanis." [8] This page was last modified on 16 January 2015, at 21:27. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.
    19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing - Wikipedia, the free ... The 19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing was a suicide bombing that occurred in a marketplace in Peshawar, Pakistan on 19 April 2010. At least 25 people died. The blast ...     19 April 2010 Peshawar bombing - Wikipedia, the free

    (May 2010) Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date This page was last modified on 20 December 2014, at 07:19.     2010 Peshawar bombings - WOW.com Search the Web. Search ... Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_2010_U.S_consulate_and_ANP_attack Updated: 2015-01-16T09:27Z Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents Attacks The American consulate attack killed 8 people including 2 security service personnel. [6] However, no Americans were hurt in the attack. The perpetrators were armed with guns and grenades and two car bombs. The security barrier was damaged, while shells from rocket-propelled grenades and hand grenades were seen in the vicinity. Police said one of the car bombs exploded at a checkpoint 50 metres from the consulate, while the other 100 kg bomb went off close to the consulate gate. At least three blasts were reported before a firefight between security forces and the attackers followed. According to Pakistan police official Ghulam Hussain, "The target was certainly the American consulate but they didn't succeed in getting there...one of the suicide bombers blew himself up close to the gate. Police guarding the US consulate started retaliatory fire. More blasts took place. We have recovered unexploded material from four different points". [5] The US Consulate General said two Pakistani security guards employed by the Consulate General were among those killed in the attack. [2] Hours earlier 44 people died in a suicide attack at a rally in the north-western town of Timergara , Lower Dir District , during a meeting of the Awami National Party (ANP), the ruling coalition in North West Frontier Province . Zahid Khan, an Awami National Party spokesperson, said his party were celebrating plans to change the name of the North West Frontier Province when a suspected suicide bomber detonated his explosives. [8] An official of the ruling ANP party, Hashim Khan Babar, told the media the attacks appeared to be in response to a major security operation which was launched in the Orakzai tribal region near Peshawar last week. [7] Perpetrators Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility for the attacks in a telephone release by Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan spokesman Azam Tariq, with the statement “We accept the attacks on the American consulate. This is revenge for drone attacks. We have already told you that we have 2,800 to 3,000 fedayeen (suicide bombers). We will carry out more such attacks. We will target any place where there are Americans” [2] The attack was revenge for Drone attacks in Pakistan . [9] A BBC analyst said the Pakistani Taliban were apparently aiming for a feat to match the one last December in Khost, Afghanistan , in which several American CIA officials were killed. [7] Repercussions An analyst in the capital said that after the government war on the Taliban the militants spread into more settled areas. He added that "The American consulate is one of the most well guarded places in Peshawar. It [the attack] was well planned and they very confidently hit their target." Al Jazeera's correspondent also noted that "Although they have been driven out of their strongholds in key areas, there is a feeling that a substantial number of those people have now infiltrated into the settled areas. There is trouble in the southern parts of the Punjab - so you do see some sort of regrouping attempt and a fear that there maybe an escalation of this sort of violence." [8] Reactions The United States embassy in Pakistan released a statement condemning the attack and saying that it reflected the "terrorists' desperation". [10] Robert Gibbs, the White House spokesmen, added: "We strongly condemn the violence and the actions. And I would point out that ... extremists in Pakistan have succeeded in killing Pakistanis, which I think hardens the view that has led to gains that have been made over the course of the year against extremism by native Pakistanis." [8] See also References External links

    Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_2010_U.S_consulate_and_ANP_attack Updated: 2015-01-16T09:27Z Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents Attacks The American consulate attack killed 8 people including 2 security service personnel. [6] However, no Americans were hurt in the attack. The perpetrators were armed with guns and grenades and two car bombs. The security barrier was damaged, while shells from rocket-propelled grenades and hand grenades were seen in the vicinity. Police said one of the car bombs exploded at a checkpoint 50 metres from the consulate, while the other 100 kg bomb went off close to the consulate gate. At least three blasts were reported before a firefight between security forces and the attackers followed. He added that "The American consulate is one of the most well guarded places in Peshawar. It [the attack] was well planned and they very confidently hit their target." There is trouble in the southern parts of the Punjab - so you do see some sort of regrouping attempt and a fear that there maybe an escalation of this sort of violence." [8] Reactions The United States embassy in Pakistan released a statement condemning the attack and saying that it reflected the "terrorists' desperation". [10] Robert Gibbs, the White House spokesmen, added: "We strongly condemn the violence and the actions. And I would point out that ... extremists in Pakistan have succeeded in killing Pakistanis, which I think hardens the view that has led to gains that have been made over the course of the year against extremism by native Pakistanis."     5 April 2010 Peshawar Bombings by Waylon Christian Terryn ... Please name your Wish List: New Wish List Submit Cancel Overview Please note that the content of this book primarily consists of articles available from Wikipedia or other free sources online. On April 5, 2010, two bombings in Pakistan killed up to 50 people and injured a 100 more. In the first attack the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar was attacked by militants. The coordinated attack involved a vehicle suicide bomb and attackers who tried to enter the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar by using grenades and weapons fire. Three explosions went off within a span of 15 minutes in the area ... Add to Bag Other sellers (Paperback) All (1) from $69.52    New (1) from $69.52    Thank you for requesting this book as a NOOK book from the publisher. Sending request ... Advertising Overview Please note that the content of this book primarily consists of articles available from Wikipedia or other free sources online. On April 5, 2010, two bombings in Pakistan killed up to 50 people and injured a 100 more. In the first attack the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar was attacked by militants. The coordinated attack involved a vehicle suicide bomb and attackers who tried to enter the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar by using grenades and weapons fire. Three explosions went off within a span of 15 minutes in the area of Saddar and Hayatabad Avenue, near the American consulate and the Peshawar headquarters of Pakistan's intelligence agency. Several militants came in two vehicles. The first vehicle exploded near a security checkpoint, and gunmen in the second car opened fire. Publication date: 12/26/2011 Product dimensions: 6.00 (w) x 9.00 (h) x 0.29 (d) Customer Reviews ( 0 ) (0) If you find inappropriate content, please report it to Barnes & Noble Why is this product inappropriate? Advertising Overview Please note that the content of this book primarily consists of articles available from Wikipedia or other free sources online. On April 5, 2010, two bombings in Pakistan killed up to 50 people and injured a 100 more. In the first attack the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar was attacked by militants. The coordinated attack involved a vehicle suicide bomb and attackers who tried to enter the U.S. Consulate in Peshawar by using grenades and weapons fire. Three explosions went off within a span of 15 minutes in the area of Saddar and Hayatabad Avenue, near the American consulate and the Peshawar headquarters of Pakistan's intelligence agency. Several militants came in two vehicles. The first vehicle exploded near a security checkpoint, and gunmen in the second car opened fire.     Changsha IRD Building bombing - Wikipedia, the free ... The Changsha IRD Building Bombings (Chinese language: 長沙稅務分局大樓爆炸事件) occurred on July 30, 2010 at about 4:15pm, and resulted in four deaths and ... Location 19 Perpetrators Unknown The Changsha IRD Building Bombings ( Chinese language : 長沙稅務分局大樓爆炸事件) occurred on July 30, 2010 at about 4:15pm, and resulted in four deaths and 19 injuries. [1] The site if the blasts was the 3rd floor of the Dongtundu (東屯渡) Inland Revenue Department [ disambiguation needed ] Branch Building in Furong District, Changsha , Hunan , China . Police announced that the explosion was deliberate. The bomb exploded under a conference table, and killed two people and seriously injured ten others on the spot; two among the wounded died after being taken to the hospital. (August 2010) This page was last modified on 1 June 2014, at 15:26. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    Changsha IRD Building bombing - Wikipedia, the free

    Location 19 Perpetrators Unknown The Changsha IRD Building Bombings ( Chinese language : 長沙稅務分局大樓爆炸事件) occurred on July 30, 2010 at about 4:15pm, and resulted in four deaths and 19 injuries. [1] The site if the blasts was the 3rd floor of the Dongtundu (東屯渡) Inland Revenue Department [ disambiguation needed ] Branch Building in Furong District, Changsha , Hunan , China . Police announced that the explosion was deliberate. The bomb exploded under a conference table, and killed two people and seriously injured ten others on the spot; two among the wounded died after being taken to the hospital. (August 2010) This page was last modified on 1 June 2014, at 15:26. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    Category:Mass murder in 2010 - Wikipedia, the free

    September 2010 Lahore bombings - Wikipedia, the free ... The September 2010 Lahore bombings were a series of three suicide bombings which occurred on 1 September 2010, in Lahore, Pakistan Thirty-eight were killed and more ... Jump to: navigation , search September 2010 Lahore bombings Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents Pakistan which has a mostly Sunni population has seen sectarian attacks against minorities including Shias who account for about 20% of Pakistan's population. It is estimated that 4000 people have been killed in religious violence over the last decade. [6] This was the third attack against Lahore's minority communities in 2010: in May two mosques were attacked belonging to the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community , and in July the Sufi community came under attack . While the government of Pakistan has banned several militant groups many of them have re emerged under different names and critics say that governments reluctance to act against them is encouraging them. [7] These were the first major attacks in Pakistan since the country was devastated by 2010 Pakistan floods . [6] The blasts targeted a procession by about 35,000 Shia to mark the death anniversary of Ali whom they consider to be their first Imam . [3] The three blasts occurred within 2,000 feet (610 m) of each other. [8] The first explosion happened in the Karbala Gamay Shah area at 6:50 pm local time. This was followed by a second explosion about 25 minutes later in Bhati chowk . The third blast happened in Anarkali Bazaar about 10 minutes after the second explosion. [5] Bodies of three suicide bombers have been recovered according to government sources. [3] Two days later the death toll rose to 38. After the blasts angry mobs attacked police stations and burnt vehicles leading to deployment of Pakistan Rangers to maintain law and order. [5] After the attack the authorities urged people not to hold outdoor religious meetings. [7] Three days of mourning was ordered by the provincial government and all private and public institutions were closed. [5] The attacks were condemned by Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani who vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. [3] The Chief Minister of Punjab Shahbaz Sharif announced compensation of Rs 500,000 for those killed and Rs 75,000 for the injured. [10] Following another attack in Quetta 2 days later, Interior Minister Rehman Malik told the press that militants want to fan the flames of sectarianism in an effort to destabilise the government followinga series of military offensives against them. He also claimed that Punjabi, such as Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, and al-Qaida and the Tehrik-e-Taliban are one and the same. [11] This page was last modified on 30 January 2015, at 01:40. Text is available under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License ; additional terms may apply. By using this site, you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy . Wikipedia® is a registered trademark of the Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. , a non-profit organization.

    September 2010 Lahore bombings - Wikipedia, the free

    Jump to: navigation , search September 2010 Lahore bombings Location ‡ indicates attacks resulting in more than 100 deaths Underline indicates the deadliest terrorist attack/s to date Contents Pakistan which has a mostly Sunni population has seen sectarian attacks against minorities including Shias who account for about 20% of Pakistan's population. It is estimated that 4000 people have been killed in religious violence over the last decade. [6] This was the third attack against Lahore's minority communities in 2010: in May two mosques were attacked belonging to the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community , and in July the Sufi community came under attack . While the government of Pakistan has banned several militant groups many of them have re emerged under different names and critics say that governments reluctance to act against them is encouraging them. [7] These were the first major attacks in Pakistan since the country was devastated by 2010 Pakistan floods . [6] The blasts targeted a procession by about 35,000 Shia to mark the death anniversary of Ali whom they consider to be their first Imam . [3] The three blasts occurred within 2,000 feet (610 m) of each other. [8] The first explosion happened in the Karbala Gamay Shah area at 6:50 pm local time. This was followed by a second explosion about 25 minutes later in Bhati chowk . The third blast happened in Anarkali Bazaar about 10 minutes after the second explosion. [5] Bodies of three suicide bombers have been recovered according to government sources. [3] Two days later the death toll rose to 38. After the blasts angry mobs attacked police stations and burnt vehicles leading to deployment of Pakistan Rangers to maintain law and order. [5] After the attack the authorities urged people not to hold outdoor religious meetings. [7] Three days of mourning was ordered by the provincial government and all private and public institutions were closed. [5] The attacks were condemned by Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani who vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. [3] The Chief Minister of Punjab Shahbaz Sharif announced compensation of Rs 500,000 for those killed and Rs 75,000 for the injured. [10] Following another attack in Quetta 2 days later, Interior Minister Rehman Malik told the press that militants want to fan the flames of sectarianism in an effort to destabilise the government followinga series of military offensives against them. He also claimed that Punjabi, such as Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, and al-Qaida and the Tehrik-e-Taliban are one and the same. [11] This page was last modified on 30 January 2015, at 01:40.
